title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the Secretary of the Air Force's direction. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors composed of Air Force general officers and senior civilian employees. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol includes members from the Air Force, Air National Guard, and Civil Air Patrol. The chairman is the senior active duty Air Force officer. The Board appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These appointees report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign Air Force personnel to serve on the staff. The Air Force and civilian employees can serve on the staff of the Civil Air Patrol. Their appointment or assignment is not restricted by laws prohibiting their participation. Those appointed to management positions in the Civil Air Patrol will not receive additional compensation. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize Civil Air Patrol members and employees as needed for administration. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors have the authority to administer the Civil Air Patrol and ensure its capability to assist the Department of the Air Force. Members and employees of the Civil Air Patrol are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from laws governing Federal employment. However, the Secretary of the Air Force can establish standards of conduct for them. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to specific requirements. The Civil Air Patrol's powers, including adopting a constitution, are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the chapter.
